q1.content:
deSEC is commited to making the Internet more secure. Our main goal is to spread the use of secure encryption technology. Private customer data are stored securely in Germany where they are protected from illegitimate third-party access (like foreign intelligence agencies): The German privacy laws are amongst the most restrictive ones world-wide.

deSEC's first product is a highly secure DNS service. Being from the 80s and not initially meant for the masses, the Internet was not designed with security in mind. Data transmitted through the Internet is by default not protected against espionage and manipulation. deSEC uses recent innovative technologies to avert such abuse, and to make the Internet more secure.

We start by cryptographically securing DNS information, to protect it from manipulation. To that end, we operate DNS servers world-wide and equipped with the DNSSEC technology, based on Google-scale infrastructure. Additionally, we increase the security of encrypted connections using DANE (see below).
q1.title: What is deSEC working on?

q2.content: The DNS technology ensures that Internet users can connect to the intended web or e-mail server when browsing the web or communicating online. To do so, it translates domain names (like www.desec.io) into a machine number (IP address) that is used for communication between computers. Being the phonebook of the Internet, the DNS also allows additional information to be stored. deSEC uses such information to validate the authenticity of encrypted connections.
q2.title: What is the DNS system?

q3.content: With DNSSEC, a client computer can verify whether DNS information was manipulated or not. That way, an Internet user can be certain to be directed to the intended web server. This is analogous to a secured phonebook lookup: If you want to talk to your bank privately, you better be certain to have the right phone number.
q3.title: What is DNSSEC?

q4.content:
As described above, DNSSEC ensures that your data is directed to the right server. But even then, attackers can intercept and read traffic before forwarding it to the intended destination. This is also true for encrypted connections. Although an attacker would have to show an electronic certificate comparable to a passport in order to decrypt the transmitted data, this requirement does not pose a significant problem to professional hackers. It is not very difficult to obtain an illegitimate decryption passport that looks valid but should not have been issued in the first place.

DANE allows to identify such attacks by adding additional passport information to the DNS database. This passport information is secured against manipulation by DNSSEC. The combination of DNSSEC and DANE has two benefits:

  • A connection to the correct server is established (for example, you're connected to your bank's server, as intended).
  • Only the bank's passport is accepted for encrypted connections. If an attacker along the way to the bank has a duplicate passport, the connection fails.

Together, these technologies allow secure and reliable online communication.
q4.title: What is DANE?

q5.content:
We are offering DNS services. Essentially, the DNS is a public lookup system to have your computer connected to the right destination (e.g. your bank). This information is, of course, public.

However, DNS information at deSEC is protected against manipulation using an additional security layer, DNSSEC. This requires a secret key which we use to lock the DNS information against manipulation. Whoever possesses the secret key can introduce manipulations.

Therefore, the secret key is located in Germany exlusively, and it is not accessible through the public Internet. Our DNS information is locked against manipulation using this key in a protected space. Only after this locking procedure, the secured information is made public in the DNS lookup database so that Internet users can rely on it to establish secure connections.
q5.title: What makes deSEC secure?

q6.content: deSEC has won a startup competition and is funded by the Heinz Nixdorf Foundation and the Foundation of German Business, from Q4/2014 to Q4/2015. This provides us with sufficient funds.
q6.title: How can deSEC provide free services?

q7.content: No, that's not possible. deSEC is not a registrar. However, each domain has DNS information that needs to be stored somewhere. Often, this is handled by the registrar where the domain was ordered. However, by letting deSEC manage the DNS information of your domain, you can benefit from DANE and other neat features.
q7.title: Can I register a domain name with deSEC? Is deSEC a registrar?

q8.content: You can set up any number of DNS records, of any type.
q8.title: Are there any usage limitations or quotas?

availability.content: Don't worry about availability of your DNS services anymore. We guarantee 100% availability of our DNS servers anytime, world-wide.
availability.title: Guaranteed Availability

dane.content: deSEC makes it easy to generate DANE/TLSA records for your site that improve encryption and security of e-mail transit between servers and lets you use self-signed SSL certificates in a secure way.
dane.title: DANE Records

dnssec.content: All zones hosted by deSEC are secured with DNSSEC to protect them from being tampered with during transmission. This helps preventing man-in-the-middle attacks on your site.
dnssec.title: Bullet-proof Security with DNSSEC

easy.content: We at deSEC know your pain when it comes to updating your DNS zones. No matter if you need to change a lot of zones at once, update single records or add records for special applications: We have an easy-to-use tool ready for you.
easy.title: Easy to Use

hero.content:
We provide secure DNS hosting with DNSSEC and DANE.
We spread innovative technologies.
We make the Internet a better place.
hero.title: Security made in Germany.

error.headline: Error While Scanning
error.text: Please make sure the hostname is valid, and there is a TLS-enabled service listening on the given TCP port.

starttls.label: Use STARTTLS with protocol:
starttls.no: (don't use STARTTLS, connect directly with TLS)

logjamscanner.headline: Logjam Scanner
logjamscanner.intro:
In May 2015, researchers published the logjam attack on TLS. Logjam uses a weakness in the TLS protocol to downgrade a connection to use 512bit Diffie-Hellman parameters. At the same time, the discrete logarithm problem, on which the security of a ephemeral Diffie-Hellman key exchange relies, can be broken within minutes for 512bit parameter size, after a precomputation of just a week. Together, these weaknesses enable a man-in-the-middle attacker to eavesdrop on the data transmitted over TLS and tamper with it.

Therefore, DH key exchange with 512bit should be considered insecure in general, and parameters with 1024bit or less should be considered to be broken for an attacker with nation-level computational resources.

This test checks the ephemeral DH parameters size of a given server and checks if the connection is vulnerable to downgrade attacks. Green rating of this test is achieved by using more than 1024bit DH parameter size (or no ephemeral DH key exchange at all), and no support for 512bit DH key exchange ("export ciphers").

deSEC is an Internet security service provider. To learn more about us, please visit our web site.

danger.headline: This Service is Seriously Insecure!
danger.text: Immediately disable export cipher suits to secure your TLS connections!

good.headline: Looks good, your service is not affected by Logjam
good.text: Your server does not support 512bit export-grade DH key exchange, and either uses large DH parameters, or does not use ephemeral DH at all.

warning.headline: Ugh, Your Service Is Vulnerable To Nation-State Resource Attackers
warning.text: While the common criminal is unlikely to eavasdrop on your connections, large government agencies may. Best upgrade to larger (at least 2048bit) DH parameters.

teaser.text: We developed a scanner for the Logjam vulnerability that is not only able to scan web servers on port 443, but also mail servers (IMAP, POP and SMTP) and jabber servers, to help people see if they need to update their servers and services.

anydns.content:
In addition to our standard features (DNSSEC, IPv6, and REST API), this package offers DANE as well as advanced reliability with a 100% Service Level Agreement.

By means of physically redundant DNS servers at various geographic locations we ensure that all DNS requests can be served reliably and as fast as possible at any time.
anydns.name: anyDNS

pricing.text: If you need more records, please get in touch with us directly.
pricing.title: Preliminary Pricing (after Beta Test)

anydns.title: anyDNS – Highly Reliable DNS

geodns.label: Optional: I am interested in geoDNS, i.e. visitor-location-dependent DNS replies, for an additional fee of 25 € per zone.

product.label: Intended pricing plan (after free evaluation; optional)

products.content: deSEC provides professional DNS hosting with IPv6 support on Google-scale infrastructure. As a matter of course, we enable our customers to secure their DNS information with DNSSEC and DANE. And best of all: During our launch phase, all services are offered free of charge.

dyndns.content:
Need to access your network attached storage at home? dynDNS allows you to assign a fixed URL to devices with frequently changing IP address, based on your domain.

This plan supports our standard features DNSSEC and REST API.
dyndns.name: dynDNS

registration.content: Did we spark interest in our DNS services with DNSSEC and DANE? We will be happy to keep you informed about the latest developments – just leave us your e-mail address.

team.headline: The Team
team.subheadline: Behind deSEC is a team of academics with both scientific as well as legal and business education. We can rely on more than 10 years of experience in both running of server infrastructure and provisioning of Internet services.
